snippet: Evidence is growing that human error contributed to one of South Korea’s worst disasters in recent decades, a ferry sinking from which 271 people are still missing.
abstract: Evidence is growing that human error contributed to sinking of South Korean ferry off southwest coast, one of country's worst disasters in recent decades; only 179 of 475 people on board are rescued, with 25 confirmed dead and 271 still missing; Korean investigators say ship's captain Lee Jun-seok stands accused of violating his responsibilities by abandoning the ferry ahead of most of passengers.

byline.original: By CHOE SANG-HUN, SU-HYUN LEE and JIHA HAM
byline.contributor: Choe Sang-Hun and Su-Hyun Lee reported from Jindo, and Jiha Ham from Ansan, South Korea. Keith Bradsher contributed reporting from Hong Kong, and Christopher Drew from New York.

lead_paragraph: Evidence is growing that human error contributed to one of South Korea’s worst disasters in recent decades, a ferry sinking from which 271 people are still missing.

headline.main: Human Error Suspected as Hope Fades in Korean Ferry Sinking
headline.print_headline: Human Error Suspected as Hope Fades in Korean Ferry Sinking
